awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Educational Data Mining Techniques to Uncover How and Why Students Learn from Erroneous Examples
awd_abstract_narration:
In this research project, a team from Carnegie Mellow University and a team from the University of Pennsylvania will use data mining techniques to explore how and why interactive erroneous examples can benefit mathematics learners. The project team will iteratively refine existing, computer-based pedagogical materials based on an analysis of log data of hundreds of students who have used those materials to learn. The work will be done with middle school mathematics students, specifically sixth grade students, and the target topic will be decimals. Recent research and studies have indicated that learning from the errors of others -- a prominent pedagogical approach used in medical education, but less commonly used in other areas of education -- has considerable potential to help students learn. Yet, erroneous examples are not used widely, in part because it is not yet understood how and why they provide this benefit. The broader impact of the project is that it will provide improved mathematics lessons, infused with erroneous examples, vetted with empirical evidence of their effectiveness, which can be deployed on the world-wide web to the significant number of U.S. students who are at risk of poor mathematics achievement due to poor understanding of core STEM concepts. The project will also provide a blueprint that can be used widely in other projects and systems, supported by both theory and empirical evidence, for how to help students learn from erroneous examples. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning.

The project will employ an iterative research plan in which log data from online learning of erroneous examples will be datamined and analyzed. The project team will start with log data from over 600 middle school mathematics students who have used erroneous examples to learn in online instructional technology and games. The team will then collect data from approximately two thousand more students over the course of the three-year project to explore whether enhancements to the erroneous examples materials based on revised theory improves student learning. Moment-by-moment learning models will be used to understand whether students learn immediately from erroneous examples, or whether erroneous examples lead to future learning. The project team will also study whether confusion and other forms of affect mediate successful learning from erroneous examples, using previously validated automated detectors of confusion and other affective states. The project team will also investigate how each of the steps of the student interaction with the erroneous examples -- for example, identifying errors, fixing errors, and explaining errors -- promote learning and positive affect. By the end of the third year of the project, the project team anticipates having a comprehensive theoretical model of how learning with erroneous examples works and how erroneous examples should be integrated into instruction more generally.

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative research project, a team from Carnegie Mellon University and a team from the University of Pennsylvania used data mining techniques to explore how and why interactive erroneous examples can benefit mathematics learners. The project team iteratively refined an existing, intelligent tutoring system based on an analysis of log data of hundreds of students who have used those materials to learn. The work was done with middle school mathematics students, specifically sixth grade students, and the target topic was decimals.

Research and studies have indicated that learning from the errors of others -- a prominent pedagogical approach used in medical education, but less commonly used in other areas of education -- has considerable potential to help students learn. Yet, erroneous examples are not used widely, in part because it is not yet understood how and why they provide this benefit.

The broader impact of the project is that it has led to improved mathematics lessons in the intelligent tutor, infused with erroneous examples, vetted with empirical evidence of their effectiveness, which is deployed on the world-wide web, accessible to the significant number of U.S. students who are at risk of poor mathematics achievement due to poor understanding of core STEM concepts. The project also has provided a blueprint that can be used widely in other projects and systems, supported by both theory and empirical evidence, for how to help students learn from erroneous examples. The project has dispersed these findings through more than ten (10) papers that have been published in journals and conference papers, as well as with the project team’s direct work with teachers at middle schools.

Besides the main target of the project -- students learning with an intelligent tutor that uses erroneous examples -- the project team was also able to explore the additional topic of learning with an educational game that also uses erroneous examples, as well as other learning science techniques. As with the intelligent tutor, the educational game targets middle school mathematics students learning decimals.  A variety of classroom studies were conducted with the game exploring key learning science issues such as the impact of self-explanation on learning, the impact of mindfulness on learning with the game, and the benefits of hints in learning with the game. Key results included: (1) female students learned more from the game than male students, across different versions of the game; (2) focused self-explanations (i.e., open-ended) led to better learning outcomes than multiple-choice self-explanations; (3) mindfulness did not benefit students, contrary to related studies, and (4) hints do not always lead to benefits in the context of learning games.

Finally, the project has also made several contributions to the research field of educational data mining space, including a generalizable automated detector of confrustion (a combination of confusion and frustration), the first automated detector of gaming the system in open-response answers, and findings around how to adapt deep learning models of student knowledge to infer latent student knowledge.
